title: How to Add Insulation to an Old House

steps.headline: Rent a blow in insulation machine and buy some bags of insulation.
steps.description: These can be rented from a local equipment rental company.

steps.headline: Locate the studs and mark the center between them.
steps.description: Then cut a hole a bit bigger than the business end of the blower nozzle with a jab knife, which is the new name for a keyhole saw, but without the curved handle and made for cutting drywall (or use a holesaw made for a drill, but wear a dust mask).

steps.headline: Make the center of the holes about 6" down from the ceiling.
steps.description: Save the drywall piece/pieces that you cut out.

steps.headline: Blow in the insulation.
steps.description: following the instruction on the blower.

steps.headline: Cut a piece of 1/2" plywood about 2" wide by 6" long.
Put the plywood piece you just cut inside the hole you just cut, and center it in the hole, hold onto it so it doesn't drop down inside the studs.
Use some 1 1/4" sheetrock screws (2 on each side) to secure the piece of wood in the middle of your hole.
Attach the round piece of sheetrock that you cut out to the piece of plywood with sheetrock screws.
Make sure all screws are tight enough so the heads are below the surface of the sheetrock.
steps.description: If it does stick out just ease it in with a hand screwdriver. It takes a light touch at the end so that you don't break the paper of the sheetrock.

steps.headline: Use taping compound to mud over the screws and your patch, press fairly hard.
Scrape off any dried mud knobs sticking out with knife and recoat.
Repeat the previous two steps at least 3 times.
steps.description: Use 100 grit paper between coats if you want, using the same sandpaper over and over. By the time you get to the final coat it will be worn down enough that paint should cover any scratches.

steps.headline: To match any texture that the wall might have, put some drywall mud in a kitchen bowl and add some water to thin.
steps.description: Practice on a piece of cardboard putting a paint brush in your mud and flicking it on the cardboard. Add more water or mud as needed and try different stuff to fling mud to get sort of a match to your current wall texture. (You can also purchase 'texture in a can' with extra spray nozzles for varying textures from most home improvement stores).

steps.headline: Use a little bit of your texture on the wall, to blend as best you can.
steps.description: Remember that once you paint, you probably will be OK with your blending.

text: Rent a blow in insulation machine and buy some bags of insulation. These can be rented from a local equipment rental company. Locate the studs and mark the center between them. Then cut a hole a bit bigger than the business end of the blower nozzle with a jab knife, which is the new name for a keyhole saw, but without the curved handle and made for cutting drywall (or use a holesaw made for a drill, but wear a dust mask). Make the center of the holes about 6" down from the ceiling. Save the drywall piece/pieces that you cut out. Blow in the insulation. following the instruction on the blower. Cut a piece of 1/2" plywood about 2" wide by 6" long.  Put the plywood piece you just cut inside the hole you just cut, and center it in the hole, hold onto it so it doesn't drop down inside the studs.  Use some 1 1/4" sheetrock screws (2 on each side) to secure the piece of wood in the middle of your hole.  Attach the round piece of sheetrock that you cut out to the piece of plywood with sheetrock screws.  Make sure all screws are tight enough so the heads are below the surface of the sheetrock. If it does stick out just ease it in with a hand screwdriver. It takes a light touch at the end so that you don't break the paper of the sheetrock. Use taping compound to mud over the screws and your patch, press fairly hard.  Allow the mud to dry.  Scrape off any dried mud knobs sticking out with knife and recoat.  Repeat the previous two steps at least 3 times. Use 100 grit paper between coats if you want, using the same sandpaper over and over. By the time you get to the final coat it will be worn down enough that paint should cover any scratches. To match any texture that the wall might have, put some drywall mud in a kitchen bowl and add some water to thin. Practice on a piece of cardboard putting a paint brush in your mud and flicking it on the cardboard. Add more water or mud as needed and try different stuff to fling mud to get sort of a match to your current wall texture. (You can also purchase 'texture in a can' with extra spray nozzles for varying textures from most home improvement stores). Use a little bit of your texture on the wall, to blend as best you can. Remember that once you paint, you probably will be OK with your blending. Prime and paint
